column1: A military life had no charms for me
column2: and I had not the faintest idea of staying in the army even if I should be graduated
column3: which I did not expect. The encampment which preceded the commencement of academic studies was very wearisome and uninteresting. When the 28th of August came—the date for breaking up camp and going into barracks—I felt as though I had been at West Point always
column4: and that if I staid to graduation
column5: I would have to remain always. I did not take hold of my studies with avidity
column6: in fact I rarely ever read over a lesson the second time during my entire cadetship. I could not sit in my room doing nothing. There is a fine library connected with the Academy from which cadets can get books to read in their quarters. I devoted more time to these
column7: than to books relating to the course of studies. Much of the time
column10: but not those of a trashy sort.
